channel.title: Dbareports on Rob Sewell (aka SQL DBA With A Beard)
channel.description: Recent content in Dbareports on Rob Sewell (aka SQL DBA With A Beard)

item.title: #TSQL2sday #94 Lets get all Posh!
item.description:
Write-Output “What are you going to automate today?”

Â 

Welcome to T-SQL Tuesday for September 2017!

T-SQL Tuesday is a chance for you to join in the SQL Server community and write a blog post on a suggested topic. It makes for a great way to find a bunch of blog posts showing the same subject from many different viewpoints. Please join in and write a blog post, maybe it’s your first ever, maybe you haven’t blogged for a while but even if you blog every day come and join the party and share your knowledge.

item.title: 2016 - That was a Year :-)
item.description: ItsÂ the time of year for reflection and I have had the most amazing 2016, I am blessed that I love what I do so much. I thoroughly enjoy writing and talking and sharing and commenting and supporting and cherishing all the SQL and PowerShell things. I wrote about using Power Bi to display my checkins. I only started thisÂ in June and this is where I have been :-)

item.title: Enabling Cortana for dbareports PowerBi
item.description:
Last week at the Birmingham user group I gave a presentation about PowerShell and SQL Server

It was a very packed session as I crammed in the new sqlserver module, dbatools and dbareports ðŸ™‚ On reflection I think this is a bit too much for a one hour session but at the end of the session I demoâ€™d live Cortana using the dbareports dataset and returning a Cortana PowerBi page.

item.title: The SQL Server Community Collaborative GitHub Organisation is born
item.description:
My wonderful friend Chrissy LeMaire and I are the creators of two GitHub repositories for SQL Server and PowerShell called dbatools and dbareports

If you are working with SQL Server I highly recommend that you take a look at the vast number of commands available to you at dbatools which will help you complete tasks within SQL Server especially for Instance migrations and also a growing number of best practice implementations

item.title: Converting SQL Agent Job Duration to TimeSpan using PowerShell
item.description:
When you look in msdb for the SQL Agent Job duration you will find that it is an int.

This is also the same when you look at Get-SQLAgentJobHistory from the sqlserver module. (You can get this by downloading the latest SSMS release from here)

This means that when you look at the various duration of the Agent Jobs you get something like this
